nodes.text: Whether retirement savings policies raise total household wealth depends on whether they act through individuals taking active choices (price subsidies) or through passive, automatic changes (employer or government automatic contributions)
Data: administrative panel for Denmark 1995-2009 with 41 million observations on retirement and taxable accounts, employer contributions, incomes, and demographics

Stylized two-type model: active savers optimize intertemporally and respond to price subsidies; passive savers set fixed pension contributions and respond only to automatic contributions or income changes
Claim: Automatic contributions (employer or government mandated) substantially increase total saving for most individuals

Evidence from firm-switch event studies and regressions: a DKr 1 increase in employer automatic contribution raises total pension contributions by ~0.949 DKr and raises total saving by ~0.777 DKr (pass-through to total saving ≈78%), robust to controls and mass-layoff subsample; effects persist for 10+ years and increase wealth at retirement

Evidence from RD on 1998 Mandatory Savings Plan (MSP): introduction of a 1% mandatory contribution at an income cutoff increases total pension contributions and total saving near the cutoff; threshold estimates imply pass-through to total saving is large (estimates ~0.85-1.27 depending on spec), indicating automatic mandated contributions raise total saving
Claim: Price subsidies for retirement accounts primarily reallocate saving across accounts (retirement vs taxables or across retirement account types) and generate little net new saving on average

Evidence: 1999 reduction in capital pension subsidy for top tax bracket caused a sharp fall in capital pension contributions; the aggregate decline was driven by ~19% of prior contributors who actively adjusted (most exiting capital pensions), while ~81% of prior contributors did not change contributions, implying majority passive behavior with respect to price changes

Evidence on crowd-out: when capital pension subsidy was reduced, ~57 cents of each DKr reduced in capital pensions shifted into annuity pensions (within-retirement shift) and roughly 99 cents of reduced retirement contributions reflected reallocation from taxable accounts (near-complete crowd-out), implying each DKr of subsidy spending produced about 0.01 DKr of net new saving (upper 95% CI ~0.28 DKr)

Claim/Result: Estimated population split is roughly 85% passive savers and 15% active savers; passive savers respond strongly to automatic contributions but not to subsidies, while active savers respond to price changes and shift across accounts

Evidence on heterogeneity: active savers are more likely to be wealthier, older, college educated and have economics/finance training; frequent reoptimizers are more responsive to subsidies and more likely to offset automatic contributions

Methods and research designs used: event studies of firm switches, OLS regressions with controls, threshold estimators, regression discontinuity for MSP, diﬀerence-in-differences around 1999 reform, 2SLS/IV for crowd-out, median/trimmed analyses to address outliers

Limitation: taxable saving measures are noisy (asset returns, timing of durables, missing home equity) making levels-based crowd-out estimates imprecise; MPS (marginal propensity to save) and threshold/median approaches yield more precise inference

Conclusion and policy implication: automatic contributions (employer mandates or automatic enrollment) are more eﬀective at increasing aggregate saving than price subsidies because most individuals are passive, subsidies produce large crowd-out and primarily benefit active, already-sophisticated savers
